WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. J.W. Maclean
Address: Beaver Lake, Sask.
Birthplace: Prince Albert, Sask.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? At Beaver Lake, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? In Medicine Hat, Alta., and Calgary, Alta.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Two or three - then more
How far was it to your nearest store? At first, 30 miles; later, 15 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two months or so
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? The usual - flour, sugar, rice, dried fruits, syrup, jam, canned vegetables, home-grown butter, canned milk.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.; taken in 25 lbs. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
How much did you use groats flour? Not much - used whole ground wheat
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢
What other grain products did you use? Oatmeal
Cornmeal? 6 lbs. 25¢
Whole wheat? Ground our own
Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a chaffing mill

Received Sept. 16/51

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Had a cow

Butter? Yes

Did you make cheese? Yes

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Salt cured pork at first

How did you get fresh meat? Only once in a while in summer

How often did you get fresh meat? Not often

How did you preserve meat? As stated above

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes

For how long? 1910-1920

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not available here

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, canned, salmon

Kinds? Salmon, cod, halibut, salmon

Price? $2.50 per lb. What other beverages were used? Coffee, chocolate, soda water, lemonade, lime juice, mineral water.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
Peas? ........... corn? Yes ....... beans? .......... Saskatoons? ...........
Other foods? ........................................................................
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1923-1924.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1924.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.
To what extent? Mostly, sometimes, rarely.
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Specify wood, gas, etc.) Where did you get your fuel? (Specify source) Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Some now use propane. We have no electricity as yet.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Specify maker) What year was it purchased? (Specify year) What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) For preparing food? (chimney, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first use enamel ware? 1916 - plus age Aluminum? 1914-1915 Bat.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Paper, Tin, cardboard, wooden cases.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - (1) Porridge, milk, cream, bread, toast, eggs & fruit
(2) Pancakes, toast, eggs, fruit

Dinner - Meat (where available), potatoes, vegetables, various desserts - such as pie & pudding or fruit

Supper - Soups, meat, potatoes, salads, fruit, bread, cake.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? _________. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Menu - Chicken & trimmings, vegetables, cranberry sauce, pudding & cake, fruits, candy & nuts etc.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No - only as an emergency in winter when trains could not get through.
1. Give a typical day's name (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate number of the family or number.

Breakfast - (1) Pancakes, bacon and eggs. (2) Toast, tea and bread.

Dinner - (usually available) potatoes, roast beef, rice pudding or fruit.

Supper - (usually) potatoes, pie, bread, fruit.

2. What was the food like in your home town? Describe the food in detail.

3. How much money would you need to obtain starting capital for your own business? Give details.

4. Would you produce foods? Give details.

5. As early as our ancestors in earlier centuries...
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

With most folk, much the same, only buy more bread, cakes, cookies and canned meats & vegetables, and more fresh fruits. Some have refrigeration.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The last few years where help is not obtainable.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In early years everyone depended on T. Eaton Co. Mail orders and sent them very large orders for supplies.

This is compiled by:

Mrs. J.W. Maclean
& Effie S. Copeland both of Dewar Lake

and is much the same as experienced by most of our neighbors.
21. Should you begin to rely on prepared foods and purchased foods instead of home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

The last few years where help is not available.

In early years everything depended on what was available.

Yours and your aunt and uncle,

Mrs. J.W. Meacham

and is much the same as experienced by many of our ancestors.
